statement.p: Find a matrix that is similar to the matrix A=\mat{1 2;3 4}

[MIT OCW] Why are these statements all true?
If A is similar to B then A^2 is similar to B^2.
A^2 and B^2 can be similar when A and B are not similar (try \lambda = 0,0).
\mat{3 0;0 4} is similar to \mat{3 1;0 4}.
\mat{3 0; 0 3} is not similar to \mat{3 1;0 3}.
Given a matrix A, let B be the matrix obtained by exchanging rows 1 and 2 of A and then exchanging columns 1 and 2 of A. A is similar to B.

ol.li: If A is similar to B, then: A=M\inv BM \implies A^2=M\inv BM(M\inv BM) = M\inv B^2 M. Since A^2=M\inv BM, by definition A^2 is similar to B^2.

There are multiple ways to verify that the given matrices are similar. One way is to explicitly find the matrix M that satisfies the similarity condition: \mat{3 0;0 4}=\mat{1 -1; 0 1}\mat{3 1; 0 4}\mat{1 1; 0 1}.

The given matrices are not similar because for the first matrix every vector in the plane is an eigenvector for \lambda=3, whereas the second matrix only has a line (y=0) of eigenvectors corresponding to \lambda=3. We know that similar matrices have the same number of independent eigenvectors, so the given matrices cannot be similar.

statement.p: If A is similar to B, and B is similar to C, are A and C also similar? If A and B are similar, are A^k and B^k also similar?

[MIT OCW] Let B be an invertible matrix, such that C=B\inv AB. A and C are similar matrices. Show that the converse is false, i.e., if A and C have same eigen values then there may not be a matrix B such that C=B\inv AB.

[MIT OCW] We say that A and B are similar matrices if A=SBS\inv for some invertible matrix S. Are the following TRUE or FALSE? Give a reason:
If A and B are similar, then A-5I and B-5I are similar.
If A and B are similar, then A^T and B^T are similar.
If A and B are similar, then AB and BA are similar.

ol.li: True. A = SBS\inv So, A^T = (S\inv)^T B^T S^T = (S^T)\inv B^T S^T
True. A=SBS\inv \implies AS = SB S(BA)S\inv = (SB)AS\inv = ASAS\inv = AB
